headline: Microwave Corn on the Cob
description: You can microwave corn on the cob easily and save on stove or grill space. Fresh summer sweet corn, ready in minutes with this no-nonsense recipe.
name: Microwave Corn on the Cob

recipeInstructions.text: Remove husk and silk from ear of corn.
Wet a paper towel, then wring it out so it's still moist. Wrap the moist towel around the ear of corn and place it on a microwave-safe plate.
Cook in the microwave until kernels are tender but still crisp when poked with a knife, 3 to 5 minutes.
Carefully remove and discard paper towel before serving.

review.reviewBody: I have cooked corn on the cob like this for years and this is the only way I cook it. I rinse of the shucked corn and leave it damp, roll it in a piece of wax paper and cook for 2 minutes. That works perfectly for me and the microwave I have. I put just enough butter on it to make the salt stick (so very little). It is great.

This is so much better than boiling where many nutrients will be wasted in the water. I have found that a square of waxed paper works great. I place the cob on the waxed paper and then drizzle olive oil and sprinkle salt on the clean cob and then wrap it up in the waxed paper sheet. That produces a plate-ready, seasoned and cooked cob with no pesky paper sticking to the corn.
quick & easy. my son liked it, I didn't have any this time (only had 2 ears), he said it tasted just fine.
I did not make any changes. It was tenderly delicious! I cooked it for four minutes. Thank you for the recipe.
It was the most perfect corn on the cob I've ever had! I used more than one paper towel and cooked it for 4 minutes. Thanks for the recipe!
Worked a dream, thanks

Even easier: put lean cob on saranwrap. Lay it across the corner and brush it with melted butter. Cover the ends of the corn with the corner of the wrap. Then fold in the rest of the wrap. Microwave for 2 minutes per cob. Serve in the wrap so that it stays hot until ready to eat! This even improves the taste of grocery store corn! Tastes like it came right from the garden!

This has become my favorite way to cook corn! I usually cook more than 1 at a time and I wait until it smells strongly cooked but not much more than 5-6 minutes for 4 ears--I go by the smell instead of the timer :)

I always microwave my sweetcorn, just cut off the floppy bits of silk, pop it in husk and all, and give it about 3 minutes. Then fold the leaves back and use them as a handle to eat it. Too easy - and delicious!
Microwave method works great!
It’s was so hot out today I decided to try this and I will never boil corn again !
I will never boil corn again! This is the easiest and fastest way to cook corn on the cob and it taste great!

I agree with wseling. Don’t worry about the wet paper. Fresh sweet corn has enough water inside to steam in husk. I have a 1000w microwave & 3m 30s is long enough to cook a whole ear. Bonus is the silk comes off really easily once cooked & you can use the husk as a holder. Maybe the paper trick would be useful if you have dehusked & frozen the corn previously. Great if this is the only thing you were cooking (as I often do for lunch)

I've been cooking my corn on the cob in the husk in the microwave for over 20 years. A co-worker taught me that trick around 1990. It's delicious!!! I have never used the paper towel though. Just place the husk on a plate and microwave it for 5 or 7 minutes on high. strip away the husk and silk, then add salt , pepper , and butter , if desired , and just enjoy!!!
awesome flavor
I rinsed the cob and tried to be sure no bugs or soil around the corn; then diried a bit before micro-waving it.

I'll never boil corn on the cob again!
I was just doing one ear so I rolled it the moist paper towel. I didn't want it to overcook so I just did 3 minutes and it was PERFECT!

Worked out GREAT !!! 

 After I " zapped " it I splashed a little real Lemon juice , Pepper and Butter .... As good as any boiled Corn
I've been making my corn on the cob this way for years. It keeps the flavor and convenient.
5 minutes destroyed a huge ear of Iowa Sweet corn. More like 2.5 to 3 minutes max.
Easy, quick and it works too! Thanks!
Very easy!
Works great! Yes you can microwave in the husk but this is easier than removing the husk when it’s steaming hot.
I did it for 3 minutes in the microwave. More than hot. Sweet, tender and delicious. This was my supper tonight

Best recipe! It was super easy and fast. 
I put my corn for 4 minutes and it was perfectly done. Very sweet and juicy! I added some butter and salt on the top and enjoyed it. 
Thanks for the recipe!

Leave the corn in the husk. Put it in the microwave and cook for 4 minutes. Place on cutting board and cut off stem end plus one row of corn. Husk and silk will slide right off. For each additional corn cob add 2 additional minutes
easy way to make corn on the cob,, loved it but you didn't say what extra ingrediant to add so I added cajun seasoning,,OH SO GOOD. MMM. LaMoine

Been doing this for years, but we butter the corn and then salt and pepper it . Then wrap it in the paper towel. Oven to mouth with no in between prep stops. You can Google cook times for multiple ears of corn and works perfect.

I make it in the microwave all the time,but not your way. I husk and clean 4 ears and place in a gallon size baggie and then place in an 1100 watt microwave for 4 minutes and it always comes out great. If I do 3 years then I reduce the time to 3 to 3 1/2 minutes. I couldn't even imagine 1 ear at 5 minutes.

Don’t shuck the corn. Instead cut off the stem end about 1/2 inch up the cob. Pop in the microwave and cook. Put on some pot holder gloves and squeeze out the corn from the tip end. all the tassel stays behind in the leaves and no need for shucking. HOWEVER, when I buy corn on the cob that is pre shucked I do it this way.
plastic wrap works for me, microwave for 2-3 minutes.
Very easy way to make corn on the cob. I added three extra minutes in the microwave for two ears of corn and it turned out perfect.
It was easy enough, but 5 minutes was way to long. I will try again using less time.
No changes made; and it was delicious.
I’m going to try it your way. My friend taught me years ago to wrap in waxed paper. It comes out so perfect that we don’t use any salt or butter!
Had to adjust for microwave power, but otherwise perfect. This is a life hack I wish I had learned 30 years ago!!!

Instead of paper towel, which might stick to the corn, I wet the corn after husking and brushing the silks, then wrapped each ear, in squares of WAXED PAPER, "butcher-style" (lay ear across one point of waxed paper, roll part way, fold in ends, and roll the rest of the way). Then I microwaved for 2 minutes per ear, fanning them out from the center of the plate.
Perfect!
Had been steaming in a rice cooker before, and this is easier to do. May try with less time.
Perfect thank you ... 5-7 mins for me
easiest way to make corn on the cob ever! Tastes great too!
Fabulous! Prepare as directed.
More like 4 minutes in my microwave. But cooked none the less.

No need to shuck or wrap the corn...just cut off a half inch of the end of the husk and cob (right through it)....put the ears on a plate...2 minutes per ear in the microwave on high.....it's very hot, so take each one off the plate with an oven mitt....squeeze each ear from the top (the uncut end) and the ear will slide right out of the husk along with the silk...ready to better and eat...
Wonderful taste and perfectly done! I rub cold butter on the ears, sprinkling on seasoning, then wrap. Extremely easy and no cleanup!
I wrapped 3 corn cobs this way and used the auto cook setting for fresh veggies on my microwave ; worked perfectly.
Excellent except that underneath the instructions there is a “partner tip” that recommends Reynolds aluminum foil, someone is gonna do that and blow up their microwave
Great for one or two people, but perfect in RV too
i haven't used paper towels for this but I have used wax paper the same way so I'm sure this will also work. it just doesn't get any easier. no pots of hot water, no mess

place in salted water in a microwave-safe bowl (no towel)
Everyone loved it

This was quick and the consistency of the corn was PERFECT. Lately I have had a corn fetish, but none of the rest of the family is on the same wavelength, so this lets me get my fix without wasting corn.
thanks
In the husk . 4 mins
The corn was perfect! And it only took 5 minutes!
I grow our own sweet corn so this recipe works fast and easy and taste great as I some times pick a couple f ears per day ( which depends on my sweet corn ripeness)
2 minutes cook
5 minutes is way too long. It over cooked it by a long shot.
I just remove some of the husk run under water and microwave husk and silk come right off!

I wrap my corn in wax paper with a splash of water added for steam, then after it's done wrap in aluminum foil to let it finish cooking and keep warm until ready to serve (the sugars in the corn stay hot a very long time). My microwave takes 4 minutes for a single ear to cook, and it comes out al dente.
couldn"t be any easier or better !!

Great and fast procedure.
Corn was perfect and very hot.
Excellent and so easy!

Don't use paper towel, rinse the corn in water, lay on a piece of saran wrap and roll up leaving ends open. 3 minutes per cob plus an extra minute on top of that. corn on the cob doesn't need to be cooked either it can be just heated up.
Easy I will make it again

I feel like my entire life has been a lie. I never would have thought that microwaving fresh ears of corn would taste as good, if not better than boiling. As long as I've been cooking, I've always boiled them, but the kitchen is so hot this time of year I decided to try it this way. Like others, I left the husk on. I am converted! Unless I'm making corn for a lot of people I'm never boiling again!
Worked out well for 3" frozen corn cobs. I would suggest ignoring the footnote, I don't think that aluminum foil will help keep the corn moist.

This is a great recipe for one ear of corn! Much easier than boiling a huge pot of water. I will say that the cooking time is a bit long for just one ear. Next time I’ll stop the cooking at four minutes and see what I think.
I did make it and it didn't turn into popcorn. Thank you
Yummy

Three mins. instead of five. It was fine.
This was yummmmm.
we do 2 minutes per ear and add one more if 4 or more cobs.
This is exactly how I've made corn on the cob for years. Great!
So easy! This is the only way I'll ever cook corn on the cob from now on.

This works ok but i prefer leaving it in the husk. Microwave 2 min turn and 2 moor min. Take knife cut stalk end off then hold silk end with towel and squeeze ear out .worked great foe me from ear one
Five minutes was wayyy too long for my microwave, I think 2-3 for one would have been perfect. A fast way to serve corn on the cob that doesn’t heat up the kitchen!!

If you like a crisp snap to your corn this is the one for you!
plus its super fast and easy, and saves on water!

As instructed, my first ear was grossly overlooked. The concept is fine but 5 minutes is way too long unless you are cooking what we call horse corn (typically late season, very large and tough kernels and big ears). We prefer younger, sweeter corn. 3 minutes per ear is ample. You can leave it unshucked until after cooking or you can do the paper towel approach. We use either, depending upon the condition of the corn.
Worked really great! Had to do them one at a time but all were cooked and not over-cooked.
??Add salt and black or white pepper if you like. It’s so easy??
I still prefer grilled on the coals corn but this is way easier.
Easy and delicious

Better to just leave in the husk as many have said. I've done it that that way for 15+ years. I run water over mine and put them straight into the microwave and roughly halfway thru I flip them over. Like microwaved potatoes, after they come out of the microwave it's best to let them rest in the husk for 10ish minutes before shucking and eating.

You want true "corn taste", strip away leaves but leave a small layer on the corn. Cut edges off but do not put in bags. Wet the corn and put in micro wave for about 4.5 minutes or desired tenderness.Flavor of the corn remain within the leaves, you will love this.
Great, easy way to make corn on the cob!! Thanks
It is so simple, quick and easy. When I take it out of the microwave I put butter and seasonings on it or Mexican street corn sauce. So delicious and would 10/10 do it again.
This is surprisingly delicious and so much easier than boiling or grilling corn on the cob. I did add a thin layer of salt on each piece of corn before I microwaved them.
I love this. My husband works nights so I find myself eating dinner with my dogs. I love corn on the cob. This is so easy and so good.

Instead of husking, def leave in the husk and cook 2min, add about 1 min per extra ear of corn. The husk provides enough natural moisture and also makes for very easy husking as it just slides right off.
Be very careful. If you use recycled paper towels, you can damage your microwave or your GFIC socket. Check your paper towel package.

I can't believe I've never done this! Great when it's so hot you don't want to use the stove. The corn is so much sweeter when you're not boiling all the goodness out of it. I microwave a half dozen and keep the ones I don't eat wrapped in the paper towel and placed in a zip lock bag in the fridge. I'll never boil another ear of corn again!
Lately, I have been soaking the corn in the husk in water, then microwave in husk for 3-4 ", then unwrap husk into a handle, rinse off hairs off the hot corn, and enjoy.

Quick and easy....tastes great!

Quick and easy! Once the corn was done, I placed butter on each ear and placed them back in the microwave until melted. Excellent!!

As I am just cooking for myself, it is much quicker than bringing a pot of water to boil, plus when corn is in season the weather is hot, who wants to heat up the kitchen boiling water? I break my cleaned ear of corn in half and place in a pyrex dish with a little bit of water, cover with the glass lid and cook on high about 2-3 minutes.
